# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Data

df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)

Here is the solution in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map((dt)->Dates.year(dt)*100 + Dates.month(dt), df.dt)
end

# Testing the function
df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)
```

This function `add_yearmonth` takes a DataFrame as input and adds a new column "ym" to it. It uses the map function from Julia's DataFrames package to apply a function (here, extracting year and month from a DateTime and concatenating them into an integer) to every element of the "dt" column. The resulting values are then assigned to the newly created "ym" column.
  
The `DateTime(2020, 5, 24)` is represented as '2020'*100 + '05', and so on for other dates.
